quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We want people that show up to our company with some fire in their belly, something that they are out to do.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A hiring bar focused on intrinsic motivation and personal drive rather than generic “talent.”

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Everyone has something, but they show up with this heartfelt intensity.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A memorable team-building heuristic—optimize for “heartfelt intensity” as a core trait across roles.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you have a team that has heartfelt intensity and is there for a purpose and something to prove, you get it.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A simple mental model for why mission-driven, high-agency teams can outperform on execution.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You give them a very exciting, ambitious product and get out of their way and they will do remarkable work.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Counterintuitive management advice: set an ambitious direction, then reduce interference to unlock output.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There's this cohort of companies like the Browser Company, [inaudible 00:01:09], a few others that are just laser focused on building the best possible user experience, almost above all else.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A strategic positioning lens: competing by prioritizing user experience as the primary objective.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So much, but how do you take it from a shiny toy to an actual business tool that helps you do your actual job?
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Frames a practical evaluation lens for generative AI: usefulness in real workflows vs. novelty.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Rytr is an enterprise-grade generative AI platform built specifically for the needs of businesses, and already widely deployed at world-class brands like Uber, Spotify, HubSpot and UiPath.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Provides concrete adoption examples that can help practitioners benchmark enterprise readiness and credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Rytr, you can break through content bottlenecks across your organization from marketing webpages to sales emails, in-product messages to creating high-quality on-brand content at scale.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable use-case framework for applying AI across multiple content surfaces to remove bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And unlike other AI applications, Rytr's training happens securely on your data and your style and brand guidelines.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Emphasizes a governance/quality methodology: align outputs by training on internal data plus brand standards.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Dovetail allows you to quickly analyze customer data from any source and transform it into evidence-based insights that your whole team can access.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Encapsulates an actionable workflow: unify multi-source customer inputs and convert them into shareable, evidence-based insights.

quotes.topic_title: What Arc is and how it’s measured
quotes.text: But so it tracks retention. It tracks engagement because five days a week is no joke. There are very few apps or pieces of software you actively use five days a week. And then, obviously, it tracks growth, because of we track the count.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A practical metric design principle: pick a single measure that simultaneously captures retention, engagement, and growth.

quotes.topic_title: What Arc is and how it’s measured
quotes.text: That is all we obsess over from a metrics perspective, because for us it captures retention, engagement, and growth in a single metric. You can't game it. Right? So from retention perspective, it's not just opening it accidentally once a week. You need to open a tab on a day in order to count as an active for a day.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Shows how to define an “ungameable” north-star metric by requiring meaningful, repeated behavior rather than shallow activity.

quotes.topic_title: What Arc is and how it’s measured
quotes.text: And then we also don't obsess over absolute numbers, because if we're successful, if you zoom out and out and out, any point in time will be inconsequential and small. So, what we really look is growth rate week over week.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A counterintuitive focus shift from vanity totals to week-over-week growth rate as the primary signal of momentum.

quotes.topic_title: What Arc is and how it’s measured
quotes.text: And for the past eight months or so, we've been growing over 10% every single week.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A concrete performance data point that anchors what “strong” week-over-week growth can look like in practice.

quotes.topic_title: What Arc is and how it’s measured
quotes.text: No. To be totally honest with you and your listeners, we have a really hard time describing Arc, which is something I'm not proud of. But it is, objectively, a replacement for your default web browser.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Highlights a positioning lesson: even with product love, unclear articulation is a real gap—so anchor on the replacement category.

quotes.topic_title: Retention numbers and cohort improvement focus
quotes.text: And then we also don't obsess over absolute numbers, because if we're successful, if you zoom out and out and out, any point in time will be inconsequential and small.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A mental model for avoiding metric fixation by focusing on what matters over long time horizons.

quotes.topic_title: Retention numbers and cohort improvement focus
quotes.text: So, what we really look is growth rate week over week. So, relative to last week, what is our growth rate?
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A practical methodology: track momentum (WoW rate) instead of absolute totals to guide execution.

quotes.topic_title: Retention numbers and cohort improvement focus
quotes.text: And for the past eight months or so, we've been growing over 10% every single week.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark showing the kind of sustained growth rate they’ve achieved and monitor.

quotes.topic_title: Retention numbers and cohort improvement focus
quotes.text: Depending on the cohort, that's somewhere between low to mid-30s and low 40s.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Specific D5/D7 retention ranges that teams can use as a reference point for a high-frequency product.

quotes.topic_title: Retention numbers and cohort improvement focus
quotes.text: And most importantly, in the same way, we don't look at absolute gross growth number, we don't look at retention in this moment. We look at, is it improving cohort by cohort?
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A cohort-based improvement lens that shifts focus from snapshot metrics to continuous retention gains over time.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lenny invited Josh and what stands out
quotes.text: I try to actually avoid founders and CEOs on this podcast to give other folks a platform who aren't often invited on podcasts.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian selection principle: intentionally biasing toward underrepresented voices as a way to broaden perspectives and surface different kinds of lessons.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lenny invited Josh and what stands out
quotes.text: But the reason I wanted to have you on is, I just feel like Arc is a remarkable product. It blew me away the first time I used it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the bar for “remarkable” product experience—strong enough to override a standing rule and create immediate user advocacy.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lenny invited Josh and what stands out
quotes.text: I don't know if you saw it, I tweeted as soon as I signed up? I had to share how awesome it was.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of a product-driven growth signal: instant, unsolicited sharing right after onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lenny invited Josh and what stands out
quotes.text: And, also as an outside observer, it just feels like you're building remarkable culture and team that's really unique.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to the idea that culture and team quality can be legible from the outside—and can be a differentiator worth studying alongside product.

quotes.topic_title: Why Lenny invited Josh and what stands out
quotes.text: I just want to selfishly learn from how you think about product and team building and all the things that go into it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical learning approach: explicitly framing interviews (or internal discussions) around extracting decision-making models for product and team building.

quotes.topic_title: Reacting to Silicon Valley: optimize feelings, not graphs
quotes.text: But what we've found is that optimizing for metrics leaves a lot on the table and it misses a lot.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that metric-first product development can systematically overlook important user value.

quotes.topic_title: Reacting to Silicon Valley: optimize feelings, not graphs
quotes.text: And so, what we do at The Browser Company is we talk about optimizing feelings. How do we want to make someone feel on the other end of our software? Do we want to make them feel joy? Do we want to make them feel fast? Do we want to make them feel organized? Do we want to make them feel focused? What is it the feeling we are trying to evoke in whatever we're doing on a specific project, or a specific feature, or a specific piece of storytelling content?
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A practical framework for defining product intent by explicitly choosing the target user emotion per project/feature/content.

quotes.topic_title: Reacting to Silicon Valley: optimize feelings, not graphs
quotes.text: By all means, numbers are a fantastic way to be honest with yourself about whether or not you are achieving what you aim to do. But at the moment of creation, at the stage as product people, wondering what should we do, and why, and how? We think it's much more important for us to think about the human, the person at the other end, and how we really want to make them feel.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A methodology for sequencing: use metrics to validate outcomes, but use human feelings to guide ideation and design decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Reacting to Silicon Valley: optimize feelings, not graphs
quotes.text: And the way that we would have that conversation would be, how many times per week do people share on Facebook? Do they post something? We even had an acronym OBPS. It's like seared into my memory. What is OBPS? And how is it trending over time? Well, I think we should have been asking, and what we at least would ask at The Browser Company and our way of product development is, "Do we think people feel closer to their friends and family?" Or something of that nature?
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A concrete example of replacing activity metrics with a higher-level human outcome question to steer strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Reacting to Silicon Valley: optimize feelings, not graphs
quotes.text: Don't optimize for metrics, don't optimize for graphs. Use that as a way to keep you honest, and use it as a tool in your toolkit. But fundamentally, none of us are here for that. We're there to make people feel something.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A memorable operating principle: treat metrics as guardrails, not the goal, and prioritize emotional impact as the north star.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing feelings with metrics as guardrails
quotes.text: if you pick the right feeling, it typically tracks pretty closely with the metric you care about.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for aligning qualitative product intent (emotion) with quantitative business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing feelings with metrics as guardrails
quotes.text: we don't have a growth team and we have no semblance of growth projects.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A counterintuitive operating choice that implies growth can be an output of product experience rather than a dedicated function.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing feelings with metrics as guardrails
quotes.text: However, in many of the new features that we put out into the world, we want people to feel surprise or joy or an emotion like that. Guess what? When people feel that way, they go, "Oh, my God, what was that?" And they start telling their friends and family about it, and they start dropping a screenshot in Slack, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A concrete example of designing for emotion to drive word-of-mouth distribution behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing feelings with metrics as guardrails
quotes.text: But I think the true answer, Lenny, is just optimizing for metrics so purely is deeply flawed in my opinion. Optimizing for feelings so purely is flawed as well.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A balanced methodology: treat metrics and feelings as complementary guardrails rather than single-objective optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Example: designing Peek for lightness and speed
quotes.text: The lucky thing is we are a very tight group of individuals that have now worked together for a long time.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Highlights a practical enabler of fast, emotion-driven product decisions: deep team cohesion can substitute for heavy process early on.

quotes.topic_title: Example: designing Peek for lightness and speed
quotes.text: So not so formal as there's a PRD at the top of it, we list out the emotions. It's much more, with that project, get Ben in a room and whoever else is working on it and say, "All right. So here's what we're trying to do for people. Here's the problem we're trying to solve or the way we fit in their day. And in that moment people want to feel very light and airy."
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Offers an actionable method: align the team via a conversation about user context and desired feeling rather than documenting emotions in a PRD.

quotes.topic_title: Example: designing Peek for lightness and speed
quotes.text: You're on Hacker News and you want to probably in pretty quick succession check out five to seven URLs.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Provides a concrete use case and behavioral detail that can guide feature design around rapid exploration workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Example: designing Peek for lightness and speed
quotes.text: So in that scenario, the conversation was how do we make it feel really airy and effortless to just whoop, pop it up, pop it back down, lightness, airiness, speed, agility.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Demonstrates a memorable design heuristic: explicitly optimize for a felt experience (lightness/speed) in a specific moment-to-moment interaction.

quotes.topic_title: Example: designing Peek for lightness and speed
quotes.text: So again, it's not that we have a, "What is the number one feeling and the number two feeling?" It is much more conversational at this stage, but I am actually really excited. Hopefully we got the privilege one day to have such a large team that we have to figure out a way to do it.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation: early-stage teams can rely on conversational alignment over formalized emotional metrics, and only later need to operationalize it.

quotes.topic_title: Shipping fast by shipping values
quotes.text: But, at risk of sounding a bit cliche, I really think we ship our values.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A simple framework: consistent shipping speed is downstream of explicit company values, not just process or tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Shipping fast by shipping values
quotes.text: If you have a team that has heartfelt intensity and is there for a purpose and something to prove, you give them a very exciting, ambitious prompt and get out of their way and they will do remarkable work.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Actionable management advice: hire for intrinsic drive, set an ambitious prompt, then remove constraints instead of over-managing.

quotes.topic_title: Shipping fast by shipping values
quotes.text: Our second value is assume you don't know. Assume you don't know.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that encourages beginner’s mind even among experts to accelerate learning and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Shipping fast by shipping values
quotes.text: And the follow up to that value is, "So we got to get going."
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A bias-to-action methodology: acknowledge uncertainty explicitly, then move immediately into exploration and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Shipping fast by shipping values
quotes.text: We have another value of, start by asking, "What could be?", which is pushing ourselves to be as aspirational, ambitious as possible.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A practical product ideation prompt that forces teams to begin from an ambitious end-state rather than incremental fixes.

quotes.topic_title: Creating values: from anti-corporate to 'Notes on Road Trips'
quotes.text: And the thing that clicked was maybe a year and a half, two years into working, I just kept hearing the same things from the team.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A practical method for discovering values: listen for repeated themes that emerge organically from team conversations over time.

quotes.topic_title: Creating values: from anti-corporate to 'Notes on Road Trips'
quotes.text: And I realized that there are some traits that define our team, extremely organically and naturally. No one told people what our values were.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Counterintuitive insight that culture/values can form without top-down declaration, suggesting leaders should observe before prescribing.

quotes.topic_title: Creating values: from anti-corporate to 'Notes on Road Trips'
quotes.text: Well, if something about the five one-liners on the corporate webpage feels off, start by asking what could be in dream a little bit.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Actionable prompt for teams dissatisfied with generic values pages: reframe the task as imagining a more authentic format and expression.

quotes.topic_title: Creating values: from anti-corporate to 'Notes on Road Trips'
quotes.text: Let's, instead of having a corporate landing page with five value titles and subtitles, let's write a manual for how to take a road trip.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A novel approach to values: encode them in a metaphorical “manual” that guides behavior more vividly than a list of slogans.

quotes.topic_title: Creating values: from anti-corporate to 'Notes on Road Trips'
quotes.text: We should put some words around it, because it's happening whether or not we like it, or say it is or not.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Practical takeaway that values exist implicitly; documenting them helps align and scale what’s already true in the organization.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical process: interviewing everyone to extract values
quotes.text: Let's sit down and interview everyone at The Browser Company. But no survey. One by one, talking to people, asking questions.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable methodology for extracting company values through direct 1:1 interviews rather than surveys.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical process: interviewing everyone to extract values
quotes.text: So, actually what's really cool about these values, if my memory serves me, I believe every single one, with the exception of maybe a word or two, was something that someone on our team said.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A practical standard for authenticity: values should be sourced from employees’ own language, not leadership-crafted slogans.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical process: interviewing everyone to extract values
quotes.text: So we interviewed the entire team and then these are meant to be a mirror.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for values as reflection of reality (a “mirror”) rather than aspirational statements.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical process: interviewing everyone to extract values
quotes.text: Probably three months.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A specific data point on timeline expectations for a collaborative values-writing process.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical process: interviewing everyone to extract values
quotes.text: Just for anyone listening, this was not CEO in a corner writing a missive. This was a team effort.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Counter to the common approach of top-down values: emphasizes collaborative authorship to increase buy-in and accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring top talent: build the company as the product
quotes.text: I don't care about web browsers. I've never cared about web browsers. I never wanted to build a web browser.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that the company’s real aim is talent and a way of working, not the obvious product category.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring top talent: build the company as the product
quotes.text: I as the CEO as notionally the head of product, I view our product as our team.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A memorable operating model: treat team-building and org design as the primary “product” to optimize.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring top talent: build the company as the product
quotes.text: It is not a new web browser. It is, let's build the dream team, our dream team. And let's build a way of working that is really fun for us and really speaks to our values.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: An actionable hiring/strategy lens: lead with values and working style to attract people who resonate with the environment.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring top talent: build the company as the product
quotes.text: Our goal of interviews is to convince people not to join The Browser Company.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A counterintuitive interview methodology that prioritizes mutual fit and reduces mismatched hires.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring top talent: build the company as the product
quotes.text: He joined the Browser Company as an IC.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A concrete example of how the company attracts senior leaders by offering high-impact work without requiring titles.

quotes.topic_title: Public celebration and credit as a hiring flywheel
quotes.text: From the very first person we hired, we celebrated them publicly. The fact that they joined. And in a very heartfelt way, telling you about them as a person and what they did.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable hiring tactic: publicly celebrate each new hire with specific, human details to build momentum and signal values.

quotes.topic_title: Public celebration and credit as a hiring flywheel
quotes.text: Again, if you think of our original mandate as building the companies, the product, when our first designer joins, we want to tell everyone about it. That's a product launch. That is the product launch.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A reframing that treats early team-building as a core product milestone, making hiring itself part of the launch narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Public celebration and credit as a hiring flywheel
quotes.text: And then, whenever we ship something, we go out of our way to celebrate the people that worked on it publicly.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: An operational practice for recognition: systematically attribute shipped work to the makers to reinforce culture and attract builders.

quotes.topic_title: Public celebration and credit as a hiring flywheel
quotes.text: I think there's a CEO-hero worship sometimes in Silicon Valley. I do very little at the company. Or sorry. I do very little as it relates to the thing people fall in love with Arc. I do a lot for The Browser Company, but I don't make Arc. I didn't make Peek.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A contrarian pushback on CEO-centric narratives that redirects credit to the people actually building the product.

quotes.topic_title: Public celebration and credit as a hiring flywheel
quotes.text: It's not going to just accrue to this like CEO figurehead who everyone thinks is some genius visionary.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A clear articulation of the cultural promise that recognition will be distributed, which can be a recruiting and retention flywheel.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public to earn trust (and risks)
quotes.text: This is one that I would really characterize as a prototype. We really have a prototype-driven culture. And this is one that I'd put high on the list of, "Maybe we'll regret this later."
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Frames public transparency as an experiment to iterate on (not a permanent doctrine), which helps teams manage risk while learning fast.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public to earn trust (and risks)
quotes.text: I'm uncomfortable putting myself too central in our story. But, naturally, when you're doing storytelling publicly, there's a gravitational pull for the CEO and the founders to be at the center of that.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode of building in public—over-centering founders—and names it as an explicit force to design against.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public to earn trust (and risks)
quotes.text: And so, building in public showing you our meetings, uncomfortably so, is an act in, "If we were them, why should they trust us? Why should anyone trust us?" We have your most sensitive personal data. We have your most sensitive professional data. Why should you trust us if we've had our trust broken again and again?
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Connects transparency directly to trust-building for high-stakes products (like browsers) where users must hand over sensitive data.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public to earn trust (and risks)
quotes.text: And so, the intention with these the building and public experiments are radical trust building. Not radical transparency, we can't share everything, but radical trust building.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Offers a practical distinction: the goal isn’t to disclose everything, but to selectively share in ways that increase user trust.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public to earn trust (and risks)
quotes.text: But I feel like I know you and that makes me trust you.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A concise mental model for why public media works: familiarity and perceived intent can create trust even without direct interaction.

quotes.topic_title: Unusual teams: storytelling and membership (prototype org design)
quotes.text: we are a very prototype-driven culture.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Highlights a core operating principle—treating culture and org design as something you can prototype, not just product features.

quotes.topic_title: Unusual teams: storytelling and membership (prototype org design)
quotes.text: It goes back to the "assume you don't know" ethos.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that encourages humility and experimentation as default behaviors in building products and teams.

quotes.topic_title: Unusual teams: storytelling and membership (prototype org design)
quotes.text: We try a lot of experiments, and we try them related to product features related to how we work together, related to the stories we tell.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to expand experimentation beyond product into collaboration norms and narrative/storytelling as organizational levers.

quotes.topic_title: Unusual teams: storytelling and membership (prototype org design)
quotes.text: And though you probably recognize or are obviously familiar with those terms, those aren't historically startup orgs, or startup disciplines and teams.
quotes.speaker: Josh Miller
quotes.context: Contrarian observation that challenges conventional startup org charts by legitimizing non-traditional functions like membership and storytelling.
